article.title: The EXO70 inhibitor Endosidin2 alters plasma membrane protein composition in Arabidopsis roots
article.abstract: To sustain normal growth and allow rapid responses to environmental cues, plants alter the plasma membrane protein composition under different conditions presumably by regulation of delivery, stability, and internalization.

sections.introduction: The plant plasma membrane serves as a selective physical barrier between intracellular contents and the environment as well as a signaling platform for transmitting information from the exterior to induce cellular responses.
sections.methods: Arabidopsis PIP2A-GFP seeds were sterilized and sowed on half-strength Murashige and Skoog (½ MS) media with vitamins, 1% (w/v) sucrose, and 0.8% (w/v) agar.
sections.results: We chose to use a transgenic line expressing PIP2A-GFP as the plant material for our experiments because PIP2A-GFP is localized predominantly at the plasma membrane by microscopy and its cellular localization is not affected by 2 h of 40 μM ES2 treatment.
sections.discussion: Using quantitative and comparative proteomics analysis, we identified 145 proteins with significantly reduced abundance at the plasma membrane of Arabidopsis roots following ES2 treatment.

article.insights_summary: Our results indicate that the plant exocyst complex mediates constitutive dynamic transport of subsets of plasma membrane proteins during normal root growth.
article.acknowledgments: We dedicate this work to the memory of CZ, who initiated and conceived the project, and unfortunately passed away on May 15, 2021.
